importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Ali Danial Hemani was indicted in 2023 on a count of violating the guns-and-drugs law after marijuana and cocaine were found at his home.
The Supreme Court agreed to review the federal law banning drug users from possessing guns on this date.
Hunter Biden was convicted in 2024 under the same law, later pardoned by President Joe Biden.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Supreme Court is expected to hear arguments in the Hemani case next year and issue a decision by the end of June 2025.

keyTakeAways: The Supreme Court is reviewing a federal law that prohibits certain drug users from possessing firearms, raising constitutional questions about the Second Amendment.
Ali Danial Hemani, a dual U.S.-Pakistan citizen, was indicted in 2023 for possessing a firearm and drugs, with the government citing his habitual marijuana use.
A federal district court dismissed the charge, citing a 2022 Supreme Court decision that requires gun prohibitions to be historically grounded.

The 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that habitual drug users cannot be targeted under the law, stating such prohibitions must be historically rooted in laws targeting intoxicated or drug-impaired individuals at the time of arrest.
The Trump administration appealed that decision, arguing that habitual drug users pose a danger to society, especially during impaired encounters with law enforcement.
The government alleged Hemani’s 2019 border phone search revealed links to Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps, and that he traveled to Iran to celebrate the killing of Qasem Soleimani in 2020.

Hemani's legal team argued that the historical basis for the law is weak and that nearly half of U.S. states have legalized recreational marijuana, implying a significant overlap between legal marijuana use and gun ownership.
Hunter Biden, son of President Joe Biden, was previously convicted under the same law in 2024 and later pardoned.
This case is part of a broader Supreme Court term focusing on gun rights, including a separate case about state-imposed bans on carrying guns on private property.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Supreme Court has agreed to review a federal law that prohibits certain drug users from possessing firearms, with the case centered on Ali Danial Hemani, a dual U.S.-Pakistan citizen indicted in 2023 for possessing a gun and drugs. The government argues that habitual drug use poses a public safety risk, particularly during impaired encounters with law enforcement, and that the law is historically justified. However, a lower court ruled that such a ban must have historical roots, and only applies to those under the influence at the time of arrest. The 5th Circuit upheld that precedent, leading the Trump administration to appeal. Hemani’s legal team challenges the historical basis of the law, noting that nearly half of U.S. states now allow recreational marijuana, creating a significant overlap between legal drug use and gun ownership. The case is part of a broader Supreme Court term examining gun rights, including a separate case on state-imposed gun bans on private property. The Court is expected to issue a decision by the end of June 2025.
title: Justices agree to review federal law banning drug users from possessing guns
